description:
The Atlantic Canadian Organic Regional Network (ACORN)'s Grow A Farmer Apprenticeship and Mentorship program promotes organic farming as a viable and empowering form of livelihood.  With a focus on farmer-to-farmer training, the program intends to cultivate, renew and diversify the organic sector in Atlantic Canada, through the preservation, growth, and use of local knowledge, land and community.



Specifically, this program, since its development in 2012, has worked to provide new and aspiring organic farmers across Atlantic Canada with curriculum-guided, organic farm-based apprenticeships with over ten different organic farms in the region; farmer-to-farmer mentorship; and training workshops and events - such as our Beginner Farmer Symposium - which have provided targeted support, education and networking opportunities for new entrants to this growing sector.

The bank exists to create a living bank of locally-adapted vegetable seed, to preserve genetic diversity, and be a resource for the Creston Valley.  Seeds are available at Kootenay Farm School seed workshops and at the Valley's annual Seedy Saturday.  Contact us to find out how you can become a Seed Bank grower!

description:
Who we serve

If you are a NEW FARMER, ESTABLISHED FARMER, OR FARMLAND OWNER, you have an important part to play in the future of agriculture and FarmLINK can help you.

If you are a new farmer (of any age!) you are a valuable part of our agricultural community, and you have an important role to play in maintaining a vibrant agricultural sector for the future. If you're like most new farmers, you probably face significant challenges ' particularly in accessing land and mentorship. This is where FarmLINK can help you make great connections!

If you are an established farmer in your fifties or older, you may be thinking about moving out of farming in the next 15 years. While passing on the farm was once a family matter, few established farmers now have children who want to farm. That said, your knowledge and experience are invaluable to new farmers, as is your productive farmland. Find creative ways to share your farm and your knowledge with tomorrow's farmers ' use resources from FarmLINK!

If you own farmland but you're not a farmer, you may be asking yourself some important questions: 
Should you rent out your farm? For what purposes and to whom? Are there tax advantages to renting your land? How much do you know about farm stewardship? Have you provided your tenant farmer with any incentives to steward your land, or discussed with them a plan for stewardship? FarmLINK can provide answers to these questions, and help you think creatively about your part in our agricultural future.
name: FarmLink.net

I grow green manure crops of peas and oats, till them in with love and sunshine and the garlic is happy. My wife is from the Navajo Nation in Arizona and I am from right here in this beautiful valley. We love being a family that is away from the four walls of any room. There are many summer activities that we enjoy, like huckleberry picking, salmon fishing, and growing our own food. Our family has a goal to eat food that is produced by us or someone we directly know.

description:
Small fry farmers living the handbuilt hobby farm dream in the sunny Okanagan.  We started with 2 alpacas back in 2010, but decided to get a bit more serious with our animal husbandry and purchased our first flock of chickens that fall.  Well the chickens truly were ‘the gateway farm animal’ that got the hay bale rolling.  We now have close to 75 birds here on our hilly little acreage, and are continuing our heritage livestock expansions with Nigerian Dwarf Goats, Olde English Southdown ‘Babydoll’ Sheep, and Heritage Registered Tennessee Walking Horses.  We also grow our own organic vegetables in summer of Kale, Tomatos, Onion, Lettuce, Beets, Sunchokes, Squash to name a few, and keep a large bee and butterfly friendly organic medicinal and culinary herb garden with Bergamont, Calendula, Mint, Sage, Echinacea, Chamomile and lots more.  In the future we would like to keep our own bees and produce honey from our herbal and wildflower gardens, we also hope to expand our vegetable garden and donate and sell the surplus to local Food Banks and Farmer’s Markets.  Our current project at the moment is working on getting our little farm SPCA certified, and looking at the idea of hiring 2-3 WWOOFERS or interns to help our expansion goals for 2014.  

In the future we would like to pilot a 'Flockshare/Herdshare' lease program for eco-conscious, land deprived, sustainably minded urbanites who would like to have their own chickens for eggs, or goats for milk/cheese. This program will build on the successful concept of community supported agriculture (CSA) and take it one step further.  We also actively encourage local young agrarians stuck living in apartments and condos to adopt bantam Old English Game hens in their homes -this very small heritage breed of chicken is smaller than the average grey parrot, and with a properly equipped cage/coop, they can live very happily inside an apartment or on a balcony and provide fresh eggs everyday, it is even simple and easy to grow small trays of fodder for real 'pastured' and happy hens!  Anything is possible when you think outside the box and we definitely do at Tangible Farm!
name: Tangible Farm

description: A quick scan of the 2011 Census of Agriculture paints a bleak picture. The average age of farmers in Canada is 55, with more than 48% over the age of 55. Only 8% of our farmers are younger than 35. The number of farmers dropped 10% from 2006 to 2011, as did the number of farms. The reasons are simple. In most of our provinces, land costs too much and farming makes too little. This is a national crisis that requires collaborative innovation between the public, private and community-driven sectors. The Smart Farm Project is an exploration of several such innovations.

We achieve this by promoting aquaponics as a means to sustainably grow food on large commercial scale as well as brining aquaponics to the passionate home growers in convenient and compact forms. We have built and operate the largest aquaponics farm in BC with over 2,000 sqft of growing space producing over 3000 vegetables a week. 2.)   To develop and provide programs on ecological agricultural methods, such as soil tillage, green manures, cover crops, composting, crop rotation, soil erosion, conservation practices, etc.

description:
Dans les campagnes du Québec, la paysannerie s'organise depuis 10 ans sous la bannière de l'Union paysanne. Agriculteurs et artisans d'une agriculture diversifiée et axée sur la communauté s'y sont reconnus. L'Union paysanne c'est une organisation ouverte à tous ceux soucieux de la Terre comme de la Table et voulant retrouver leur autonomie.

In rural Quebec over the past ten years, the peasant movement has been organizing under the banner of the Union paysanne, which has created a space for farmers and artisans who are practising and promoting a diversified and community-based agriculture. The Union paysanne is an organization
that is open to all who are concerned about the land and the food that is produced on it, and who wish to regain their autonomy as producers and consumers.
name: Union Paysanne

description: Wildsight works locally, regionally and globally to protect biodiversity and encourage sustainable communities in Canada's Columbia and Rocky Mountain regions. We envision a landscape with free-running streams and rivers of pure water, extensive and connected wild spaces and natural habitat that maintains the full complement of indigenous plants and wildlife. We see healthy human communities thriving with sustainable livelihoods and lifestyles based on a conservation ethic. Food security work is included in our mandate - this is especially true for our Kimberley/Cranbrook branch. We manage the Kimberley Farmers' Market.
name: Wildsight -Kimberley Cranbrook Branch

description: We are people in the community who identify food insecurity as an important health issue in Cranbrook. Our projects include the East Kootenay Local Food Guide and the Public Produce Garden.

description: The West Kootenay EcoSociety protects the natural environment while building a just and sustainable post-carbon world. Our primary focus is increasingly local, both by design and necessity. We recognize the need for personal and cultural transformation in order to create the social, economic, and environmental conditions for sustainability. Our agri-food programs include the Cottonwood Market and Nelson Dowtown Local Market.

description: The Windermere District Farmers' Institute and Livestock Association (WDFI) represents the interest of_ the agricultural community from Canal Flats to Golden.__ It was incorporated in 1914 and has been in continuous operation ever since. The WDFI supports local agriculture in many ways. An important ongooing project is the establishment of a community abattoir.

description: SEEDS is an intergenerational non-profit society. It does not receive any secure funding and relies upon the generosity of individual donations, membership fees, in-kind donations, special events, and grants. SEEDS stewards vibrant and educational organic gardens, where community comes together to learn, and to grow nutritional vegetables. Volunteer seniors provide mentoring and hands-on learning at the Greenhouse and the nearby Outdoor Community Gardens in Nelson's Lakeside Park. SEEDS is certified as Kootenay Mountain Grown Organic.

description: Slocan Valley based not-for-profit co-operative working on food security measures for the West Kootenay region. The board is made up of young farmers and food business owners who have a vested interest in strengthening the food economy. Projects include Far Food Fork, kootenayfood.com, and the documentary Feeding Ourselves.
name: West Kootenay Permaculture Co-op Association

description: The Queen Bee Project is a grassroots organization dedicated to the promotion of natural beekeeping, and increasing awareness about the importance of the world's leading pollinator, the honey bee. The project was founded by Christina Yahn, who received a grant in 2010 to research plant essence derived treatments for Varroa mites. As a result of this research, she has developed a variety of all-natural plant essence combinations from medicinal herbs to care for honey bees and promote bee health through a holistic approach.The philosophy of The Queen Bee Project is to nurture this process by encouraging the diversification of local food production and increasing medicinal plant forage vital to bee survival. By continuing to foster a harmonious relationship between bees and farmers, we not only protect food production, but also provide safe habitat for our pollinators.
name: The Queen Bee Project

description: ncorporated in August 2004, the HerbPro Cooperative grew out of a rural community economic development initiative in the BC Rockies. Our mission is to to supply the finest premium quality herbs and botanicals to our customers in the natural health products and natural foods sector. Members grow, harvest and dry herbs, and the HerbProCoop does final milling of herbs and botanicals based on our buyer specifications. All inventorying, marketing, sales, shipping and distribution is done by HerbPro.

description: Kootenay Local Agricultural Society is a not for profit Kootenay based local agricultural organization dedicated to the production and promotion of local agriculture and products. As the owner and certifier of the Kootenay Mountain Grown label, we are responsible for ensuring that only farmers and processors that meet the Kootenay Mountain Grown standards for organic agriculture can market their product as Kootenay Mountain Grown. We support the goals of Community Food Security, which means that all people have dignified access to food that is safe, nutritious, and culturally appropriate, and which has been produced in a manner that is environmentally, and socially sustainable. WE operate a tool library with tools for small-scal sustainable agriculture available for rent.

Much of the work that we all share involves harvesting, washing and packaging. When we're not doing that we plant, weed, and seed our next round of crops. Most of the work is done by hand at our scale, though we do have an ever-growing set of tools to make things easier. It's a fast-paced job, but we have fun doing it.

description:
A national registered charity founded in 1993, we work with over a third of the universities in Canada, and our programs have been run in over 100 communities across the country. For over 20 years, Meal Exchange has been supporting students to develop innovative solutions to address hunger, food insecurity and sustainability on their campuses and with communities.
 
At Meal Exchange, we believe that post-secondary campuses are an ideal leverage point for tackling food security and sustainability in Canada, and that student leaders have the power to drive this change. We provide these students with mentorship and resources, and connect them with their peers and stakeholders across the country.
name: Meal Exchange

description:
Founded in 2008, the Farmlands Trust (Greater Victoria) Society’s mission is to enhance farming capacity in the Greater Victoria area by protecting local farmland, protecting eco-sensitive and culturally special areas, producing food for those in need, providing relevant educational opportunities, promoting the economic viability of farmland, and providing community access and public awareness programs. 

Through our work, the FLT Society liaises with a diverse community: Greater Victoria farming community;  First Nations communities in Greater Victoria; Government (municipal, provincial, federal); food banks, senior centers, drop-in centers for persons in need in society; non-governmental organizations (NGOs) specializing in stewardship, heritage, agriculture and/or nature conservancy; and academia.
name: The Farmlands Trust (Greater Victoria) Society

description: We provide online stores for sustainable food producers: Barn2Door is like an 'Etsy' for farmers, fishers, ranchers, and foragers!

description: Our sustainable agricultural initiative is designed to grow and support local food systems by connecting local farms, producers and apprentices to local restaurants, grocers and community members. Through a variety of education, outreach and apprenticeship programs, we’re protecting our agricultural landscape, improving health and wellness and catalyzing investment and job creation in urban and rural environments.

description: Dirt Works Incubator Farm, the first of its kind is South Carolina, provides infrastructure and support to reduce the risks for new farmers launching their new farm businesses for up to three years. Participant low cost fees include acreage, access to a tractor, packing facility, walk-in cooler, tool storage, irrigation and assistance from a mentor farmer. The initial 10-acre parcel located on Walnut Hill Plantation, Johns Island, is divided into 1-2 acre plots for up to 6 farmers and a 1-acre Teaching Plot for apprentices, students, and the public. During the last year of the program, farmers are matched with prospective landowners to continue to expand their farm business.  We are currently taking farmer applications for Fall 2015-Spring 2016.
name: Dirt Works Incubator Farmer

description: The BC Association of Abattoirs was founded in 2009 to collectively address the challenges and build on the opportunities facing provincially licensed producers and processors to provide consumers with safe, high quality meat and poultry products for commercial markets in British Columbia.

description: The McGill Food Systems Project is a collaborative initiative between Students, Professors, McGill Food and Dining Services, and the McGill Office of Sustainability. Using student research, community engagement, and stakeholder collaboration, we work to maximize the environmental, social, and economic sustainability of the food systems of McGill’s downtown campus. Our goal is to get members of the campus, regional community, and food supply chain working together create a food system they can be proud to eat from.
name: McGill Food Systems Project

description:
The Concordia Greenhouse Project is a collectively run, consensus-based, non-profit organization. It uses the Henry H. Hall Building 12th floor rooftop greenhouse as an all-organic space geared towards community, education and sustainable horticulture. The Greenhouse is a year-round green space that hosts workshops, projects and events raising awareness around food issues and alternatives to mainstream consumerism.

We aspire to strengthen the urban agriculture movement at Concordia University and in Montreal by growing local produce using ecological practices, providing experiential learning opportunities through volunteering, internships and jobs, and networking with other like-minded individuals and organizations.
name: Concordia Greenhouse

description: 5-40 acres of certified organic land available for an organic farmer. Field includes irrigation and tractor available for rent. You will need to provide a business plan and show a commitment to growing your future business, looking to lease land for a year to start and build relationship, then negotiate a long term plan.  Willing to discuss ideas and partnership/share options. Contact Jacob Wiebe  at wiebe445@yahoo.ca

description: Community Futures is a community based, not-for-profit organization offering a selection of business services, employment services and community economic development projects. Are you starting, expanding or purchasing a farming business?  Community Futures can help with loans for start-up costs, operating capital, equipment, and inventory purchases, or business purchase costs. Community Futures loans range from $1,000. to $500,000, and are offered with flexible terms and competitive rates.  We look forward to helping you find a financing solution to meet your farming needs.

description: MSEG is a 3-acre, student-run ecological garden at McGill's MacDonald Campus for Agriculture, Environment and Nutrition Sciences. As the only experiment in organic farming at the institution, the project seeks to provide students and community members with hands-on experience in small-scale sustainable agriculture, and connect various stakeholders across campus around issues of food security. MSEG employs 6-7 full-time student interns from all areas of study throughout the spring/summer. Past employees/project managers have gone on to start their own farms, work for community organizations, or pursue further studies in food sustainability. MSEG currently manages a 50+ member CSA program, participates in two local farmers' markets and sells some produce directly to McGill's dining services.

description:
OKANAGAN MOBILE JUICING: MobileJuicing.com is a family owned and operated apple, cherry and berry mobile trailer, making great tasting juice from your fruit. Our clean, professional service provides you with your very own pasteurized and packaged juices, ready for resale or personal use.

Our sophisticated mobile juicing trailer travels to all the fruit growing regions in BC, namely the Okanagan, the Similkameen, Kootenays and the Lower Mainland. We are capable of processing approximately 900 litres of juice per hour and packaging it into convenient and environmentally friendly Bag-in-Box style packaging for its optimal storage and preservation properties.
We also offer 1.5L “Pouch-Up” for cherry and berry juices and bottling service for your custom bottles.

We de-stone and process cherries, peaches, plums, etc, puree berries and other soft fruit, and of course make delicious juice from apples and pears! We service both conventional and organic growers, we are certified organic processors through P.A.C.S.

Contact us with any questions regarding our mobile juicing services, the process, or make an enquiry about booking the mobile juice trailer today.

description:
We have land in west central Alberta that is a mix of forest and cleared grass land. The soil type is grey wooded, although we are in the lower foothills and the geology is considered to be glacial till. There are a few rocks in the soil.  We are located 180 km west of Edmonton and about 30 km north of Highway 16.  The nearest community is Edson, Alberta, 40 km to the southwest. There is a large, established vegetable garden with apple trees and a variety of fruit bushes, all fenced. It is well proven to be very productive. The well has good quality water and flow. Land elevation is 945 metres. There is potential for another dwelling on the property.

We no longer have the time or energy to maintain this land base but want to continue to live here.  We are looking for an individual or a couple who are looking for land to carry out small scale market farming in a very rural setting.
name: Ficht Farm

description: Kootenay and Boundary Food Producers’ Co-operative is a marketing and distribution organization working to increase agricultural production and consumer access to healthy local food from Creston to Grand Forks, Argenta to the border. This will be accomplished by: a. Developing services and infrastructure to streamline transactions between food producers and customers b. Building agricultural capacity and infrastructure c. Developing educational and marketing opportunities to increase farm viability in the region, and d. Such other activities as are necessary and desirable for these purposes. We are looking for new farmer and processor members, and welcome community support.

description:
Are you looking for an experience of a lifetime where you can share your expertise and learn from others? Why not consider being an international volunteer?

Uniterra is a leading Canadian international volunteer cooperation and development program, jointly implemented by the Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI) and World University Service of Canada (WUSC). 

Uniterra contributes to improving the socio-economic conditions of poor and marginalized communities in 14 countries and with over 200 partners in Africa, Asia and the Americas through the exchange of expertise and knowledge of Canadian and international volunteers.  Uniterra believes that economic growth, when inclusive, is the most powerful driver of poverty reduction. The purpose of the Uniterra program is to improve  the lives of some of the world’s most vulnerable populations by stimulating growth and facilitating access to the benefits of growing and diversified markets. To make this happen, we are working with our local partners to enhance the income of poor and marginalized women and youth  through better access to employment and income generation opportunities. Uniterra country program staff work with our local partners to design Uniterra assignments in the context of the country strategy, supporting the inclusion of women and youth in key economic subsectors. 
For more information on the Uniterra program, our approach and countries of focus please visit: Uniterra.ca
name: Uniterra - a WUSC and CECI program

description: FarmLead.com is a risk-free, transparent online and mobile grain marketplace that allows grain buyers and sellers of any size to list, negotiate directly with one another, and finalize grain trade connections from anywhere and at any time. FarmLead.com is not an auction, but a marketplace that automatically creates a better grain marketing and/or procurement strategy. From ratings on all users, to making sure as a farmer that you're guaranteed payment on your grain, we try to manage as much risk as possible. Thus, whether you're a grain producer, end-user, broker, or trader, FarmLead.com is most efficient & cost-efffective asset when it comes to the chore of buying and/or selling grain.
name: FarmLead Online Grain Marketplace

description: The Harvest Moon Society envisions a world in which healthy land and communities are celebrated by all, leading to equitable food systems, a sense of place, and care for the environment now and in generations to come.
